720396f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from, but not including, 34th Street. In the centre is the Seventy-First Regiment Armory. In a few years this site will be occupied by the New York Herald Building.
About 1885.
New York Edison Company Collection.

720146f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue &. Broadway, at West 34th Street as viewed northward from the Dime Savings Bank on 32nd Street. In the foreground is the triangular plot identified as Greeley Square. The "El" station at the left is at 33rd Street Across the tracks is the continuation of Broadway with the old 71st 1nf. Regiment Armory to the right. Partially appearing on the right is the Broadway Tabernacle at 34th Street.
Prior to 1892
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Neg. #2018

717402f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from and including 34th Street. The brownstone church in the right foreground is the Broadway Tabernacle. The only buildings shown which are familiar to modern eyes are the New York Herald Building, which is shown in the right centre; the Hotel Normandie, in the centre background, which will be demolished in 1928; and the Metropolitan Opera House, in the left background, which will still stand in 1936, with every prospect of surviving for some years to come. Also shown is the Herald Square Theatre, on the N.W. corner of 35th Street, and the Hotel Marlborough, on the west side between 36th and 37th Streets.
About 1895.
Brown Brothers.

709433f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue and West 34th Street,showing the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church,organized in 1840, and building erected in 1859.
About 1900
No record.

717403f-a.text:
Broadway at the S.W. corner of 34th Street, showing some of the buildings which are about to be demolished for the erection of the new Saks Department Store, which will later be known as
Saks-34th Street.
19O1.
Ewing Galloway.
Neg # 763

709430f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue (left), at the S. W. corner of West 34th Street (right), showing the site of the later Saks Department Store. Note the saloon on the left operated by Jim Corbett, the Worlds heavy weight champion. On the right is Marsh's Restaurant & Cafe.
About 1901
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717404f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from West 34th Street. The buildings to the left of the center were removed for the Macy Dept. Store. The Herald Square (formerly Park) Theatre is at the N. W. corner of 35th Street. In the block above is the Hotel Marlboro. On the right appears the Metropolitan Opera building.
About 1901
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717405f-a.text:
Broadway at the N.W. corner of 34th Street. Almost the entire picture is taken up by the department store of R. H. Macy & Company; but the corner building itself is not a part of the store.
About 1922.
Underwood & Underwood.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

717406f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from 34th to 38th Streets, showing also 34th Street, north side, west from Broadway. The large building in the center is Macy's Department Store. Above it is the Johnson Building; the Lefcourt-Marlborough Building, on the site of the old Marlborough Hotel; the Lefcourt-State Building; and the BrickenBroadway Building, on the site of the old Broadway Theatre.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.

717409f-a.text:
R. H. Macy & Company, one of New York City's largest department stores, Broadway, west side, from 35th to 34th Streets. In the foreground is the former Seventy-First Regiment Armory, half of which has been demolished for the construction of the Herald Square Building.
January 30, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

731236f-b.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Macy's Thanksgiving Parade.
731236f-b.text:
(1)
Macy's Thanksgiving Parade, 1932, No. 18.  Releasing the balloons at Macy's Store, 34th Street at Broadway, seen from and including Seventh Avenue.
At the end of the parade, at Herald Square, the balloon are released and allowed to rise and blow away.  A catch prize is offered to the lucky boy or girl who can find one of these balloons and bring it back to Macy's the next day.
Here goes the jaguar.  The alligator and the bear are seen in the street below.  These pictures incidentally give  splendid view of the Empire State Building, the tallest in the world.
November 24, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 19.  The Dachshund follows.
November 24, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 20.  The pig rises in the air.  The alligator is still waiting below; and the jaguar can still be discerned, up in the air above the Empire State Building.
November 24, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

733325f-b.title: Street scenes - Shoppers and crowds.
733325f-b.text:
(1)
Typical noonday street rush at Sixth Ave., and 34th Street, when towering skyscrapers literally belch humanity into the streets.
About 1921.
(2)
Christmas shoppers at 34th Street and Broadway; one of the World's
busiest corners.
December 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

733325f-a.title: Street scenes - Shoppers and crowds.
733325f-a.text:
(1)
Typical noonday street rush at Sixth Ave., and 34th Street, when towering skyscrapers literally belch humanity into the streets.
About 1921.
(2)
Christmas shoppers at 34th Street and Broadway; one of the World's
busiest corners.
December 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

712163f-a.text:
West 34th Street, east from Sixth Avenue, showing prominently pavement conditions after the removal of the former streetcar tracks by the W. P. A. At the right margin is the Hotel HcAlpin. Beyond, at Fifth Avenue, is the base of the towering Empire State Building. To the left of the latter is MoCreery's and Altman's stores.
February 7, 1937
W. P. A., photo
Five Boroughs Project

712164f-a.text:
West 34th Street, west from Broadway, showing pavement conditions after the removal of the former crosstown street cars and their necessary tracks. The latter were eliminated through the assistance of the W.P.A. Note the new bus service on the left. At the right is Macy's Department Store extending westward to Eighth Ave.
February 7, 1937
W. P. A., photo
Five Boroughs Project

709431f-b.text:
(1)
6th Avenue, south from W. 34th Street, showing the "Eg" structure and its 33rd Street Station. This was mainly patronized by shoppers to Gimbels, Sak's and Macys. The first two of these enterprizes appear here occupying the 34th - 33rd and 33rdd-32nd Street frontages. Note the
interstore bridge con ecting these.
Views 2 and 3 show the absence of the "Eg" and the station remaining. This will remmain for about a month and then join the balance of this structure. Dnderground, at this date, the 6th Svenue Subway is under construction. At the left is Broadway, which intersects with 6th Avenue and leaves two triangular parks; the southerly of which
(Greeley Square) appears partially here.
Viows 1,2 and 3tApril 5, 1939.
P.L.5perr

1507867.title: 34th Street (West) - Broadway - Seventh Avenue, north side
1507867.folder: 34th Street (West) - Broadway - Seventh Avenue, north side, Manhattan, NY

712165f-a.text:
Interior Macy's Dept. Store N.Y.C.
Shoppers at Macys.

709434f-a.text:
Sixth Ave., east side, north from but not including 34th Street.
February 5, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

720147f-a.text:
Broadway south from west 34th Street, also south on 3ixth Avenue The triangular plot in the center is Greeley Square and acboss it is the Un'on Dime Savings Tank Building a west 33nd 3treet.
M2BR.  A.

720395f-a.text:
Broadway, north across West 34th Street. At the right is the open triangular area, Herald Square, identified with the distinctive Herald Building at it's base. This is formed by the intersection of Broadway and Sixth Avenue.
About 1901
Gift of Urbrock Collection  ea EtGSS

720397f-b.text:
Herald Square, north from West 34th Street, showing Broadway (left) intersecting Sixth Ave. (right, elevated line thereon). At the apex (West 35th Street) is the 3-story Rogers Peet Building (formerly the New York Herald Building). At the rear of same and occupying the balance of the triangle is the new 24-story Herald Square Building.
September 29, 1931
P. L. Sperr.
Broadway & 5th Ave. Neg. A-243  July 18, 1941
P.L. Sperr
Broadway from below 33rd St. Neg. A-120  July 18, 1941
P.L. Sperr

717407f-a.text:
1919-1921 Broadway, west side, between 34th and 35th Streets, one of the buildings to be torn down for the erection of the
department store of R. H. Macy & Company.
1901.
Ewing Galloway.
